Centro de Investigación y Desarrollo en Ciencias Aplicadas (CINDECA) Facultad de Ciencias Exactas Universidad Nacional de La Plata (UNLP)-CONICET Calle 47, 257 La Plata CP 1900 Argentina Two Zr-beta zeolites were synthesized using different methods. Method 1 consisted in the formation of a dealuminated zeolite beta seed followed by Zr incorporation and thermal treatment (ZBZr1). In Method 2, zeolite beta was prepared and then, the dealumination and subsequent Zr incorporation were performed (ZBZr2). These materials were tested in the ketalization of glycerol with acetone and compared with a SBAsulf. Both preparation methods incorporate Zr in the zeolitic framework, and no ZrO2 is detected. Method 1 developed crystallites with an average size of 260 nm, Si/Zr ratio ∼100, total amount of acid sites of 0.375 mmol.g−1 and a ratio of Brönsted to Lewis acid sites of 1.9. In the case of Method 2, values of 1500 nm, ∼86, 0.32 mmol.g−1 and 0.7 were obtained, respectively. The ZBZr2 sample presented low catalytic activity, possibly due to diffusion limitations. The turnover frequency (TOF) was calculated as 44.84 and 60.37 min−1 for ZBZr1 and SBAsulf , respectively. After one cycle of reaction, both ZBZr1 and SBAsulf showed a decrease in the glycerol conversion, however, the selectivity remained constant in the ZBZr1 material after the reaction cycle and the catalytic activity could be reestablished after a thermal treatment. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Zr-zeolite beta Ordered mesoporous silica Sulfonic SBA-15 Solketal Glycerol Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Biomass is one of the most abundant renewable resources. The efficient development of processes and technologies using this resource as raw material is vital to solve today's ecological and energy problems [1]. Glycerol is a platform molecule with several applications in industry, and is coproduced in the productive process of biodiesel [2]. Nowadays, the development of new technologies capable of adding value to glycerol has become of great interest for the biodiesel industry. In the literature, several studies focus in glycerol valorization by catalytic processes such as ketalization, dehydration, oxidation, and reforming. In particular, the ketalization of glycerol to produce oxygenated compounds, like solketal, has become attractive for diverse applications. Solketal is a cyclic ketal used as an anti-knock agent in naphtha formulations [3], as a solvent in pesticide formulations [4] and pharmaceutical formulations [5], and is also used in the synthesis of polyester resins [6], polyglycerols [7] and plasticizers [8]. In literature reports, the ketalization of glycerol with acetone (Scheme 1 ) is carried out using heterogeneous catalysts like ionic exchange resins [9], heteropolyacids [10], acidified clays [11], mesostructured silicas [12–14] and zeolites [15–17]. Several authors have recently studied this reaction using catalysts with Lewis acid sites [18–20]. Da Silva et al. synthetized Sn(II) salts and silicotungstic acid (Sn2SiW12O40) and compared them with other heteropolyacid salts and homogeneous catalysts. The results showed that the primary structure was not affected by the exchange of protons with tin cations, and the catalytic activity of the Sn2SiW12O40 material could achieve a conversion near 99% with a selectivity of 97%, showing a better performance than other heteropolyacid salts. This material presented a stability of 4 reaction cycles, without any appreciable loss in the catalytic performance, or changes in the IR spectra in the Keggin anion [18]. Kao et al. prepared a series of SiO2 with supported niobium oxide, using the chemical vapor deposition method to remove Cl from the surface of the sample. The catalytic tests showed that the glycerol conversion was improved with the addition of niobium in the catalyst until a Nb to Si ratio of 15% wt%, reaching a conversion of 45% with an 80% selectivity towards solketal [19]. Among the catalysts studied in this reaction, zeolites represent one of the most promising materials for a technological application. Zeolites are widely used as heterogeneous catalysts in the petrochemical industry, petroleum refining, and organic synthesis [21]. The use of zeolites, under their protonated form, in the ketalization of glycerol has been previously studied. Da Silva et al. studied zeolites with structures BEA, ZSM-5 and USY, observing a better performance in the zeolite beta compared with the USY, achieving conversions of 85% and 55%, respectively in 30 min of reaction, while zeolite ZSM-5 only converted 25% glycerol in 30 min. The lower activity of zeolite ZSM-5 was attributed to the smaller size of its pores, which impeded the formation of solketal into the pores [22]. Poly et al. studied the influence of the Si/Al ratio of protonated beta zeolites and determined that the hydrophobicity of the material increased with the Si/Al ratio while the density of acid sites decreased. In the performance of these materials in different glycerol acetalization reactions, the authors observed that the material with a Si/Al ratio of 75 was the most effective one with an initial reaction rate of 11.3 mmol.h−1.gcat −1 in the acetalization of glycerol with 2-pentanone [23]. Kowalska-Kus et al. improved the activity of zeolites ZSM-5 and beta with a desalinization and a subsequent acid treatment, which allowed obtaining conversions of 90% in the zeolite ZSM-5, and improved the stability of the zeolite beta in a 24 h online reaction [24]. Recently, the incorporation of transition metals in BEA structures has attracted the attention of diverse researchers due to their capacity to activate a carbonyl group [25,26]. In particular, beta zeolites with incorporated Zr in their structure have been used in reactions with the Meerwein-Ponndorf-Verley mechanism, as the reduction of furfural [26,27], cyclohexanone [28,29], 1,4-cyclohexanedione [25] and methyl-levulinate [30]. In general, Zr-Beta zeolites have two types of Lewis acid sites: Zr atoms tetra coordinated in structural positions (closed sites) and Zr atoms tetra coordinated with a Zr-OH group (open sites). Sushkevich et al. have proved that the acid strength of the Lewis acid sites associated with open Zr (IV) sites is stronger than those associated with closed sites [31]. Paniagua et al. synthesized Zr-Al-Beta zeolites as a bifunctional catalyst with Brönsted and Lewis acid sites for the one-pot production of γ-valerolactone (GVL) from glucose. The authors determined that the Al/Zr ratio has a strong impact on the product distribution as higher content of Zr produces a higher amount of GVL, obtaining a maximum at a ratio Al/Zr = 0.2 [32]. Li et al. doped Zr-Beta zeolites with La in order to enhance the ratio of Lewis to Brönsted (L/B ratio) acid sites of the material for the reduction of cyclohexanone. Despite the increase in the L/B ratio, the catalytic activity of the materials with higher incorporation of La showed a decrease in the catalytic activity due to the blockage of micropores by excess La [32]. Gao et al. synthesized an alkali promoted Zr-Al-Beta zeolite to regulate their active sites. The characterization results showed that, through the simple alkaline treatment, the Brønsted acidic sites and Lewis acidic sites of Zr-Al-Beta were transformed and weakened significantly by alkali-metal cations, which greatly promoted its catalytic performance and coking resistance ability in the conversion of furfural to furfural alcohol [26]. Taking into account that in the presence of Lewis acid sites, the ketalization of glycerol proceeds with a mechanism similar to the one mentioned above [33], the use of this material in the solketal synthesis looks promising. The objective of this work is to study the influence of the synthesis methodology of Zr-beta zeolites on its acid, its morphological and textural properties. For this purpose, two Zr-beta zeolites were synthesized by two different methods, i.e. Method 1 in which a seed of zeolite beta was introduced into a solution containing a source of Zr and Si and then subjected to a thermal treatment [34], while Method 2 consisted in the dealumination of a crystallized zeolite beta, and the subsequent incorporation of Zr in its structure [35]. The work also studied the stability of these materials and compared their performance with an SBA-15 catalyst functionalized with sulfonic groups, which had a similar acid strength but different textural properties. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The chemicals used in this study were Poly(ethyleneglycol)-block-poly(propyleneglycol)-block-poly(-ethyleneglycol) (PE-PP-PE Pluronic P123, Aldrich), tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS, 98%, Aldrich), hydrochloric acid (HCl, Baker), 3-Mercaptopropyl-trimethoxysilane (MPTMS, 95%, Aldrich), hydrogen peroxide (H2O230 vol%, Panreac), metallic aluminum (Mallinckrodt chemical works), tetraethylammonium hydroxide (TEAOH, Aldrich), fumed silica (Degussa), nitric acid (HNO3, Anedra), Zirconyl chloride octahydrate (ZrOCl2.8H2O, Aldrich), hydrofluoric acid (HF, Cicarelli). Glycerol (99.5%, Cicarelli), solketal (98.2, TCI Chemicals, used as standard for GC analysis), acetone (99.5%, Anedra), n-propanol (99.3%, Anedra, used as external standard for GC analysis), 2.2 Synthesis of catalysts 2.2.1 Sulfonic SBA-15 SBA-15 mesoporous silica was functionalized with organosulfonic groups using 3-mercaptopropyl trimethoxysilane as a precursor. The procedure was carried out using the sol-gel technique, by co-condensation of MPTS and TEOS in the presence of Pluronic 123, in an acid medium of HCl. The solid product was recovered by filtration and air-dried at room-temperature overnight. The template was removed from the as-synthesized material by washing with ethanol under reflux for 24 h. The oxidation stage of the mercaptopropyl groups was carried out by immersing the obtained solid in an aqueous solution of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2 30% in vol) following the methodology described by Bossaert et al. [36]. After the oxidation treatment, the solution was filtered and the solid was washed with ethanol. The wet material was suspended (1 wt%) in a H2SO4 solution (1 M) for 2 h. The powder was then washed with water and ethanol and dried for 2 h at 120 °C. The molar composition was: 1 TEOS: 0.11MPTMS: 0.018PEO: 6.5HCl: 27.1H2O. The sample was named SBAsulf. 2.2.2 Zr-zeolite beta Synthesis of dealuminated zeolite beta seeds Nanocrystalline zeolite beta seeds were prepared following the methodology described by Zhu et al. and Camblor et al. [34,37]. The appropriate amount of metallic Al was dissolved in tetraethylammonium hydroxide (TEAOH) (40 wt% aqueous solution). This solution was then added to a mixture made by dispersing fumed silica in deionized water and the mixture was homogenized by stirring 2 h (molar composition of final gel: 1.0 SiO2:0.56 TEAOH:0.02 Al2O3:15 H2O). The mixture was treated at 140 °C for 72 h under autogenous pressure in a teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. After the thermal treatment, the solid was separated by centrifugation (10,000 rpm, 90 min), washed with deionized water until pH < 9 and dried at 100 °C. Dealuminated zeolite beta seeds were prepared by treatment of 1 g of zeolite with 50 ml of 6 M HNO3 at 80 °C for 24 h. The solid was recovered by centrifugation, washed with deionized water, and dried at 10 °C. The sample was named ZBseed. Synthesis of dealuminated Zr-zeolite beta from the prepared seed (Method 1) After hydrolyzing tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) with tetraethylammonium hydroxide (TEAOH), a solution of ZrOCl2·8H2O in water was added, and the mixture was stirred until all the ethanol formed by the hydrolysis of TEOS was evaporated. HF and dealuminated zeolite beta seed crystals were added. The final gel composition was 1.0 SiO2:0.02 ZrO2:0.56 TEAOH:10 H2O:0.56 HF. The crystallization was carried out in a teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave at 140 °C for 20 days. The solid product obtained was filtered, washed with deionized water, dried at 100 °C, and calcined at 580°C for 4 h. The sample was named ZBZr1. Synthesis of dealuminated Zr-zeolite beta (Method 2) Al-zeolite beta was prepared in a fluoride medium following the procedure reported by Corma et al. [35]. The sample was treated with 12 M HNO3 at 80 °C for 20 h to remove the aluminum. After that, the dealuminated zeolite beta was added to a solution of ZrOCl2.8H2O and the mixture was dried at 80 °C for 15 h. Zr-zeolite beta was obtained by calcining at 600 °C for 8 h. The sample was named ZBZr2. 2.3 Characterization of catalyst The crystalline phase of zeolites was determined by powder X-ray diffraction. The powder patterns were collected in an X-pert Pro Panalytical diffractometer using the CuKα radiation in the 2θ angle range from 5° to 60° (step size of 0.04°). The JCPDS database was used to identify the crystalline phases. SEM Particle size and morphology were observed by SEM by means of a Philips 505 microscope. For preparation of samples, a small amount of sample was places on carbon tape and sputter coated with gold. TEM images were acquired in a JEOL JEM-2100 Plus transmission electron microscope equipped with an EDS Oxford X-MAX 65T. The observations were performed in HRTEM and HAADF mode, obtaining images and X-ray spectra at an acceleration of 200 kV. The samples were dispersed in ethanol using an ultrasonic bath and placed on a micro grid. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed using a dual monochromatic Ag/Al source and a hemispherical electron energy analyzer (PHOIBOS 150). Spectra were collected with monochromatic radiation Al Kα. O 1s, Zr 3d, Si 2p, and C 1s lines were monitored. C 1s at 284.6 eV was used as a charging reference. Spectra were analyzed with CasaXPS software. Textural properties of the catalysts were calculated from nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms, which were recorded at the temperature of liquid nitrogen (-196 °C) using a Micrometrics ASAP 2020 Plus 2.00 instrument. Before adsorption, the zeolites and the mesoporous silica were outgassed by heating at 300 °C and 100 °C, respectively, with a pressure lower than 4 × 10−2mbar during 12 h. The surface area was calculated according to the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation [38]. The total pore volume was taken at the P.P0 −1 0.989 single point. Micropore surface (Smicro) and micropore volume (Vmicro) were estimated using the t-plot method. FT-IR spectra were collected by means of a Bruker IFS 66 Fourier transform infrared equipment, using KBr in the frequency range of 4000–400 cm−1. The amount and strength of acid sites in all samples were determined by potentiometric titration. A known mass of the solid to be analyzed was suspended in acetonitrile. The suspension was titrated using a solution of n-butylamine (0.1 mol L−1) in acetonitrile at 0.05 ml.min−1. The electrode potential variation was recorded in a digital pH meter (Metrohm 794 Basic Titrino apparatus with a double junction electrode). The amount and strength of acid sites in the zeolites were also evaluated by Pyridine temperature-programmed desorption (TPD). Approximately 10 mg of catalysts, sandwiched by quartz wool, was loaded in a quartz tube. The catalysts were pretreated in-situ in N2 flow (30 ml min−1) at 350 °C for 1 h. After cooling down to room temperature, the sample was saturated with pyridine. Then, pure nitrogen was flowed, and the temperature was increased up to 150 °C, maintaining this temperature until no physically adsorbed pyridine was detected. The TPD experiment was carried out heating at 12 °C min−1 in nitrogen flow from 150 °C to 750 °C. Pyridine coming out of the sample cell passed through a methanation reactor. A H2 stream was also fed to this reactor, quantitatively converting Pyridine to CH4, using a Ni catalyst. The CH4 was continuously measured by a FID detector. The calibration of the system was carried out with pulses of 1.26% CO2/N2. The nature of the acid sites was studied by infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), employing pyridine as a probe molecule. Typically, a self-supporting wafer of the zeolite was activated in vacuum at 723 K for 1 h (10 K min−1). The activated sample was cooled down to 298 K to collect the spectrum. Then, it was heated to 423 K (10 K min−1) and exposed to pyridine vapor during 1 h, followed by a purge of 1 h under vacuum at the same temperature to eliminate the physisorbed base. The saturated sample was cooled down again to 298 K for the collection of the spectra. The experiments were carried out in a Shimadzu IR Prestige 21 equipment equipped with a high-energy ceramic source and a LiTaO3 high-sensitivity pyroelectric detector. 2.4 Catalytic test The glycerol ketalization with acetone was carried out in a 200 ml Büchi glass reactor equipped with a manometer, magnetic stirring, thermostatic bath, and gas inlet and release valves. Before the catalytic evaluation, experiments were performed to verify the negligible contribution of the reaction in the absence of a catalyst. The Mears criterion values were below 10−5, and the Weisz-Prater criterion values below 10−8, confirming that both external and internal diffusion limitations are negligible on the operation conditions. As in a typical experiment, the reactor was loaded with a 1:6 molar ratio of glycerol to acetone, and an adequate quantity of the catalyst. Then, the reactor was pressurized to 0.2 MPa with N2 and heated to the desired temperature. Once the experiment was over, the reactor was cooled to 20 °C, and the catalyst was separated by centrifugation and filtration. The reactants and products were analyzed by gas chromatography with a Shimadzu GCMS-QP505A, equipped with a PE-Elite-Wax capillary column, and a FID detector, using n-propanol as an external standard. The conversion was determined with the following equation: X % = ( i n i t i a l g l y c e r o l m o l e s − f i n a l g l y c e r o l m o l e s ) i n i t i a l g l y c e r o l m o l e s and the selectivity to solketal with: S % = s o l k e t a l m o l e s ( i n i t i a l g l y c e r o l m o l e s − f i n a l g l y c e r o l m o l e s ) 3 Results 3.1 Catalyst characterization Fig. 1 shows the X-ray diffraction pattern obtained for samples ZBseed, ZBZr1 and ZBZr2. In all samples, the characteristic peaks of the beta zeolite structure are observed for 2θ =5–9° and 2θ =20–24°, discarding the collapse of the zeolitic structure caused by the dealumination and incorporation of Zr [39]. However, a loss of crystallinity with Zr substitution can be detected. It is worthwhile noting that peaks corresponding to bulky ZrO2 are not detected in these samples, this result indicates an insertion of Zr in the structure of zeolite beta. The superficial coverage of zirconia species was explored by XPS. The results of the XPS measures show a Si/Zr atomic ratio of 102.6 and 86.4 for samples ZBZr1 and ZBZr2, respectively (Table 1 ). No traces of Al were detected on the external surface of both materials. The binding energies for the Zr 3d5/2 photoelectrons in both samples (Fig. 2 ) appear to be shifted to higher energies (∼183,8 and ∼186,2 eV), compared with the binding energies of bulk ZrO2 (182.0 and 184.5 eV) [40]. This shift is due to a more electron-deficient Zr present in Zr-O-Si bonds and it is consistent with the formation of intra-framework Zr species in Zr-Beta zeolite [29,41,42]. SEM analysis of zeolites ZBZr1 and ZBZr2 (Fig. S1) were performed to determine the crystallite size and morphology. Results show that crystallite size of zeolite ZBZr1 varied from 50 to 400 nm with an average size of 260 nm. For zeolite ZBZr2, the crystallite size was in the range of 750–2200 nm with an average size of 1500 nm. Both solids have a spherical morphology. Fig. 3 show the HAADF-STEM image with elemental mapping of the material ZBZr1. A homogeneous dispersion of Zr and the presence of Al in a Si/Al atomic ratio of ∼180 on ZBZr1 was observed. On the other hand, in ZBZr2 (Fig. S2) the amount of Al detected was negligible. The difference with the results observed by XPS revealed that the small quantity of residual Al is located in the bulk of the zeolitic structure in ZBZr1. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of all materials are shown in Fig. 4 and the values of the textural properties are presented in Table 1. According to the IUPAC classification for the isotherm shapes [43], the ZBZr1 sample exhibits a type I isotherm, typical of microporous structures, while ZBZr2 and SBAsulf exhibit type IV isotherms, characterized by the presence of a hysteresis loop. For zeolites, the presence of the hysteresis loop in the pressure range corresponding to capillary condensation indicates the structural modification of the original ordered microporous arrangement towards a more disordered micro-mesoporous material, induced by the dealumination treatment and the subsequent incorporation of zirconium. In the case of the mesoporous silica, the presence of the sulfonic functional groups changes the pressure range where the hysteresis loop was positioned. In fact, the expected value for the hysteresis loop closure at P.P0 −1>0.42, typical of the non-funcionalized SBA-15, was observed closing down at P.P0 −1<0.4 for SBAsulf, indicating the occurrence of pore blockage as a drawback of the functionalization [44]. Fig. 5 shows the infrared spectra corresponding to the original SBA-15 sample and after functionalization (SBAsulf). In both materials, the spectra show the bands around 1200, 1070, 794 and 470 cm−1 assigned to the typical Si–O–Si stretching and bending vibrations of condensed silica network, and the peaks around 960 cm−1 corresponding to non-condensed Si–OH groups. The broad band around 3400 cm−1 and the peak around 1630 cm−1 are due to the stretching and bending vibrations of adsorbed H2O [45,46]. In the spectrum corresponding to sample SBAsulf, the Si–O stretching band at 1200 cm−1 broadens towards higher wavenumbers and increases in intensity, due to the S=O stretching vibration mode associated with the absorption bands observed at 1201 and 1121 cm−1 [47]. The signal corresponding to the SH group is not observed at 2600 cm−1, indicating that the presence of non-oxidized groups is not detected by this technique [48,49]. Additionally, the bands at 2940 and 600 cm−1 are due to C–H and C–S stretching vibrations [47,50]. The FTIR spectra of materials ZBZr1 and ZBZr2 (Fig. 6 ) show the characteristic bands of the structural vibrations corresponding to beta zeolites (527, 578 and 626 cm−1), Si-O-Si vibrations (470 cm−1), Si-O vibrations associated with uncoupled SiO4 (986 cm−1), vibrations associated with external symmetry and asymmetries (803, 1256 cm−1) and internal symmetries (1090 cm−1) of O-T-O links (T = Zr, Al or Si), vibrations associated with adsorbed H2O (1630 cm−1) [51], vibrations of internal Si-OH groups (3438 cm−1) [52,53] and OH groups bound to Zr (3634 cm−1) [54]. When comparing both samples, a lower intensity in the band located at 986 cm−1 in the ZBZr1 sample is observed. Additionally, an increase in the intensity of the bands located at 803 and 1256 cm−1 is also noted. This phenomenon suggests that in the zeolite synthetized by Method 1, the amount of Zr and Al in the structure is higher than the zeolite synthetized by Method 2. By means of potentiometric titration with n-butylamine, it is possible to estimate the strength and the number of acid sites present in a solid. It is considered that the initial potential (E0) indicates the maximum strength of the acid sites present in a solid. The acidic strength of surface sites can be assigned according to the following ranges: very strong site, E0 > 100 mV; strong site, 0 < E0 < 100 mV; weak site, −100 <E0 < 0 mV and very weak site, E0 < −100 mV. If the titration curve changes the concavity, it is considered that the point of inflection indicates the presence of more than one type of acid site [55]. Fig. 7 shows the potentiometric titration curves for all materials. The initial potentials and the number of acid sites estimated by this technique are summarized in Table 1. All the materials present very strong acid sites (E0 > 100 mV), according to the initial potentials (E0) obtained, following the order: SBAsulf> ZBZr1> ZBZr2. A higher value of E0 of the SBAsulf sample indicates a significant strength of the sulfonic acid groups and a total amount of acid sites of 0.54 meq n-butylamine.g−1 is detected for this sample. For the synthesized zeolites, the amount of acid sites is similar in both samples (∼ 0.30 meq n-butylamine.g−1), while the strength of the acid sites in the Zr-zeolite beta synthesized by Method 1 is considerably higher than that in the zeolite synthesized by Method 2. Fig. 8. A shows the pyridine TPD profile for sample ZBZr1. By means of this technique, it was possible to quantify a total amount of acid sites of 0.375 mmol.g−1 in this material. In order to infer about the acid strength of the active sites in the catalyst, the deconvolution of the profile is also shown in the figure in order to allow identifying and quantifying acid sites of weak, moderate and strong strength, according to the temperature of pyridine desorption. In this material, 61% of the acid sites are very strong, with a maximum desorption temperature at approximately 660 °C. Then 33% of sites can be considered of moderate strength, with a maximum located at 480 °C. The amount of weak acid sites in this material is very low (6%), detected by the presence of a peak at approximately 360 °C. Therefore, it can be concluded that sample ZBZr1 is a material that in average presents high strength acidity (in agreement with the initial electric potential detected during the titration). In the case of the ZBZr2 catalyst, the total acidity detected was 0.32 mmol.g−1, resulting slightly less than that of the previous sample. In this case, the TPD profile can be deconvolved mainly into two main types of acidic sites (Fig. 8B). First, a high temperature region, where a maximum with desorption at 660 °C can also be observed in this catalyst, in agreement with the stronger acid sites detected in sample ZBZr1. For sample ZBZr2, this area of the TPD profile represents about 70% of the total acidity, although a small contribution from acid sites of intermediate strength could be considered. However, it is important to note that this material has a significant proportion of weak acid sites, representing 30% of the total acidity, with a maximum desorption at 400 °C. This difference compared with the ZBZr1 material is attributed to the absence of Al in the zeolitic structure of ZBZr2. In the case of SBAsulf, potentiometric titration with n-butylamine was the only technique selected to study the acid sites since Pyridine TPD experiments involve heating the sample, added to the fact that the presence of carbon in the functional groups interferes with the FID detection. The nature of the acid sites in both Zr-zeolites was determined by an FTIR analysis of adsorbed pyridine (Fig. S3). Two characteristic bands at 1545 cm−1 and 1455 cm−1 related with pyridine adsorbed over Brönsted (B) and Lewis (L) acid sites respectively are present in both materials [56]. For quantification, the molar extinction coefficients determined by a combination of microgravimetric and FTIR spectroscopic analysis of adsorbed pyridine were used [57]. The ratio of Brönsted to Lewis acid sites was estimated as 1.9 and 0.7 for ZBZr1 and ZBZr2, respectively (Table 1). The higher ratio of B/L acid sites observed in ZBZr1 is in concordance with the presence of Al in the zeolitic structure. 3.2 Catalytic activity Fig. 9 shows the glycerol conversion in the ketalization reaction for the catalysts under study. The ZBZr2 material showed a very small catalytic activity (∼5% after 100 min of reaction) revealing that a higher proportion of weak acid sites not only impacted in the total acid strength of the material (observed by the lower initial electric potential in the titration experiment), but also reduced the catalytic performance in the ketalization reaction. In the literature it was reported that zeolites with high Si/Al ratios show better glycerol acetalization performance in comparison with zeolites with low Si/Al ratios due to high hydrophobicity. In our work, ZBZr2 has a Si/Al ratio higher than the sample ZBZr1, although its catalytic performance is poor. The lower catalytic activity of the zeolite could also be related to the different nature of the acid site. However, in the literature, Li et al. [33] reported the catalytic activity of a rage of materials with different ratios of Lewis and Brönsted acid sites like Zr-TUD-1 (B/L = 0.24), Hf-TUD-1 (B/L = 0.23), and Sn-MCM-41 (B/L = 0.13), observing TOF of ∼5.4 min−1 for all materials. On the contrary, when using a catalyst with a higher density of strong acid sites, but with a lower micropore size like the ultrastable zeolite Y and higher B/L ratio (B/L = 1.96), a TOF of 0.9 min-1 was observed. Silva et al. [58] also studied the catalytic activity of a catalyst with Lewis and Brönsted acid sites. In their study, they determined that the Lewis acid sites of a homogeneous catalyst like Fe(NO3)3 were more effective in the reaction than homogeneous catalysts with Brönsted acid sites, such as H2SO4 or p-toluenesulfonic acid (PTSA). In addition, we have tested the activity of the Al-zeolite beta prepared in Method 2, and we have observed a similar catalytic performance to ZBZr2. Therefore, we can conclude that the major proportion of Lewis acid sites could not be responsible for the lower catalytic activity of ZBZr2. Manjunathan et al. [59] reported the effect of the crystallite size in the catalytic activity in the solketal synthesis using beta zeolites as catalyst. The authors observed that the material with an average size of 135 nm could reach an 86% glycerol conversion, while the material with a larger crystallite size (450 nm) could reach a 38% conversion even presenting a higher acid density. In this work, the catalyst ZBZr2 has a larger crystallite size and a smaller acid strength, therefore it is expected that the material ZBZr2 has a lower catalytic activity than material ZBZr1 due to diffusive effects. For all active catalysts, only solketal and the isomer 2,2-dimethyl-1,3-dioxan-5-ol were identified as products, with a selectivity higher than 85% towards solketal, and reaching a 98% selectivity towards solketal near the equilibrium conversion. This behavior was expected due to a lower thermodynamic stability of the isomer compared to solketal [60,61]. SBAsulf catalyst showed a high reaction rate in the first stage of the reaction, making it possible to achieve a conversion near the chemical equilibrium in 1 h of reaction using a catalyst to glycerol ratio of 1,2 wt%, showing a direct relation between the acid site density from SBAsulf and ZBZr1 and the glycerol conversion. The null activity of ZBZr2, despite having a similar density of acid sites than ZBZr1, is explained by the influence of the diffusion effects in ZBZr2. Table 2 shows the initial reaction rate (estimated in the first 10 min) and the turnover frequency (TOF) calculated from the density of acid sites (estimated by potentiometric titration). The lower catalytic activity of the acid sites of the zeolite could be related with a lower proportion of strong acid sites. Studies of the ketalization of glycerol using H-Beta zeolites as a catalyst have observed TOF of 7.89 min-1 [62] and 26.79 min-1 [59] over commercial zeolites with Si/Al ratios of ∼8 and ∼25, respectively. These results show that the Brönsted and Lewis acid sites produced by the combination of intra framework Zr and Al are more effective in the synthesis of solketal than the acid sites of commercial beta zeolites. 3.3 Catalytic stability With the purpose of studying the stability of the catalysts, after a reaction cycle, the materials were recovered from the reaction mixture and dried at 200 °C (SBAsulf) and 300 °C (ZBZr1) before being subjected to another cycle (post-reaction). After one reaction cycle (Fig. 10 ), the observed conversion dropped from 78% to 38% in SBAsulf and from 78% to 40% in ZBZr1. In the case of selectivity, a drop from 97% to 81% was observed in SBAsulf, while in the case of ZBZr1, the selectivity dropped from 98% to 96%, only. The smaller drop in the selectivity of ZBZr1 could be related to a steric effect occurring in the micropores of the material, hindering the formation of the bulkier 6-membered ring isomer. The decay of the catalytic activity observed in both materials in this work could be related to a strong adsorption of the products or reactants on the surface, which could deactivate some active sites, or produce a blockage of the pores, hindering the access of the reactants to the active sites. To study this effect, catalyst ZBZr1 was subjected to a thermal treatment at 580 °C for 1 h, and the SBAsulf material to a lavage with ethanol (Treated). After these treatments, both materials were subjected to another cycle, observing a better performance in ZBZr1 than in the catalyst without any treatment. On the contrary, the SBAsulf catalyst did not show any improvement after treatment with ethanol. Based on those previous results, the FTIR analysis of the samples post reaction was performed. Fig. 11 shows the FTIR spectra of the fresh and post-reaction SBAsulf catalyst. It can be observed that for both samples the ratio between Si-O-Si, Si-OH and SO3 is similar. Therefore, the material does not suffer any change in the structure or loss of functional groups. New bands on 1415 (methyl group), 1466 (C-H associated with a ring), 2307, 2369, 2900 and 2950 cm−1 (alkyl group) appear on the spent catalyst, with an increase in the band of the OH groups (3000–3700 cm−1), which are associated with the presence of hydroxyl groups, possibly from unreacted glycerol adsorbed on the material (∼3300 cm−1) [63,64]. In the ZBZr1 material (Fig. 12 ), an increase of the bands located at 625 cm−1, 520 cm−1, and 470 cm−1 is observed, which is associated with the characteristic vibrations of C-O-C-O bonds of acetals, and an increase of the band located at 1215 cm−1 associated with C-O bonds of alcohol groups [65], indicating that solketal is adsorbed on the spent catalyst. The new band located at 3230 cm−1 in the spent catalyst is associated with intramolecular hydrogen bonds [65], indicating the presence of adsorbed glycerol on the sample. After a thermal treatment at 300 °C, the bands associated with C-O-C-O bonds in ZBZr1 decrease, reaching an intensity similar to that of the fresh sample. Therefore, the adsorbed solketal could be easily desorbed with a thermal treatment at 300°C. On the contrary, the partial decrease of the band located at 3230 cm−1 indicates that there are still adsorbed species on the catalyst which explain the decreased activity in the second cycle. With this analysis, it is observed that the blockage of the pores produced by the adsorption of glycerol or solketal is one of the most important deactivation mechanisms of the solid [17,66]. 4 Conclusion The influence of the incorporation methodology of Zr on beta zeolites in the glycerol ketalization has been studied over two Zr-zeolite beta, and a SBA-15 catalyst functionalized with sulfonic groups (SBAsulf) was used for comparison purpose. The characterization results showed us that a well-crystallized Zr-zeolite beta with different acidic and textural properties can be obtained by the immersion and subsequent thermal treatment of dealuminated zeolite beta seeds in a solution containing Si and Zr (ZBZr1, Method 1) and by the dealumination of a crystalline beta zeolite, and the next incorporation of Zr in its structure (ZBZr2, Method 2). SEM analysis show that the crystallite size of zeolite ZBZr1 has an average size of 260 nm and the zeolite ZBZr2 has an average crystallite size of 1500 nm. The ZBZr1 material (E0= 440 mV) showed an acid strength similar to SBAsulf (E0= 550 mV) with a smaller density of acid sites and a B/L ratio of 1.9. The material ZBZr2 shows a weaker acid strength (E0=175 mV) and a density of acid sites similar to ZBZr1 and a B/L of 0.7. ZBZr1 and SBAsulf achieved the equilibrium conversion at 40 °C after 180 and 60 min of reaction respectively, while ZBZr2 shows a low catalytic activity (conversion of 5% after 300 min of reaction). The higher catalytic activity of material ZBZr1 could be related with a smaller crystallite size (260 nm for ZBZr1 and 1500 nm for ZBZr2) which induces a faster diffusion of the reactive molecules in the zeolite channels. Regarding the stability of the materials, after one cycle of reaction, both ZBZr1 and SBAsulf, showed a decay of the glycerol conversion. However, the selectivity remained constant in ZBZr1 (∼96%), possibly because the formation of the isomer on the active sites located in the micropores is hindered by a steric effect. A further study with IR over the spent catalysts revealed that the adsorption of solketal and glycerol is one of the most important factors in the decay of the catalytic activity post-reaction. The catalytic activity of the ZBZr1 material could be reestablished after a thermal treatment at 580 °C. CRediT authorship contribution statement Julián A. coredata.dc:description: Two Zr-beta zeolites were synthesized using different methods. Method 1 consisted in the formation of a dealuminated zeolite beta seed followed by Zr incorporation and thermal treatment (ZBZr1). In Method 2, zeolite beta was prepared and then, the dealumination and subsequent Zr incorporation were performed (ZBZr2). These materials were tested in the ketalization of glycerol with acetone and compared with a SBAsulf. Both preparation methods incorporate Zr in the zeolitic framework, and no ZrO2 is detected. Method 1 developed crystallites with an average size of 260 nm, Si/Zr ratio ∼100, total amount of acid sites of 0.375 mmol.g−1 and a ratio of Brönsted to Lewis acid sites of 1.9. In the case of Method 2, values of 1500 nm, ∼86, 0.32 mmol.g−1 and 0.7 were obtained, respectively. The ZBZr2 sample presented low catalytic activity, possibly due to diffusion limitations. The turnover frequency (TOF) was calculated as 44.84 and 60.37 min−1 for ZBZr1 and SBAsulf , respectively. After one cycle of reaction, both ZBZr1 and SBAsulf showed a decrease in the glycerol conversion, however, the selectivity remained constant in the ZBZr1 material after the reaction cycle and the catalytic activity could be reestablished after a thermal treatment.
coredata.dc:title: Al-free Zr-beta zeolite as a selective catalyst for the ketalization of glycerol
